newsitem.title: USA: American Airlines seeks new $1 billion credit line.
newsitem.headline: American Airlines seeks new $1 billion credit line.

text.p: American Airlines, facing the possibility of strike by its pilots, said Friday it was borrowing $1 billion from a credit line and has arranged to borrow another $1 billion under a new credit agreement.

Meanwhile, Florida Sens. Bob Graham and Connie Mack asked President Clinton to help the airline and the pilots reach an agreement to avoid a walkout that would cripple their state's winter tourism business.

The carrier based outside Fort Worth, Texas gave notice it was drawing $1 billion under the existing credit line, which expires in 2001, in a filing with the federal Securities and Exchange Commission.
It said it had not yet borrowed from the new line of credit and did not say how it would use the funds.
American, a unit of AMR Corp., is the dominant air carrier at Miami International Airport, a key gateway for passengers and cargo to Latin America.
In a letter to the president, Graham and Mack said a strike beginning Feb. 15 would be "costly" and "painful."

"If a settlement is not reached, a mid-February holiday weekend airline strike would disrupt passengers and the flow of freight across our nation and overseas, particularly in our hemisphere," the letter said. "Nowhere would the harm be more acute than in Florida."

Pilots' leaders have said they want to win a new contract now, even if it involves a strike, rather than risk lengthy arbitration. Earlier this week, a senior union leader predicted a 50 percent possibility of a strike, and that it could last up to 60 days.

Starting Monday, the two sides are to begin five days of "supermediation" in a last-gasp effort to reach a new four-year labour contract. Those negotiations will take place in Washington with the help of the National Mediation Board.

Pilots are demanding pay raises of more than 11 percent over the life of the contract, improved stock options and a guarantee that American will not use its American Eagle commuter carrier, which employs pilots of another union, to fly 50-passenger regional jets.
